title: Experience
description: Scroll to see how my story has unfolded through the years.

items.title: Bachelor of Arts in Languages & Cultures of Asia
items.description: In seeking to combine a deep understanding of different viewpoints with practical research and critical thinking skills, I opted to pursue a degree in South Asian area studies with a linguistics focus. This opened up opportunities for an undergraduate fellowship and intensive language study with an international program component, ultimately leading to an academic year abroad in Varanasi, India.

links.title: Undergraduate Fellowship
links.description:
In the fall of 2008, I was selected for an undergraduate fellowship position with the UW's Lubar Institute for the Study of the Abrahamic Religions.

The Lubar Institute was founded to create better understanding of the Abrahamic traditions and their interrelationships by encouraging ongoing discussion of these traditions among scholars, members of those traditions, and the general public. The Institute's projects aim to broaden conversations across academic disciplines and faith traditions, between believers and non-believers, and, in upholding the Wisconsin Idea, to bring together campus and community by inviting engagement with the general public.

links.title: Honor Society Inductee
links.description:
Based on having completed 72 semester hours with a GPA in the top 7.5% of my class, I was nominated and accepted into the Phi Kappa Phi National Honor Society in the spring of 2009.

Since its founding in 1897, Phi Kappa Phi has initiated many notable members, including public servants and leaders, Pulitzer and Nobel Prize winners, NASA astronauts and more. It is a global network composed of the best and brightest from all academic disciplines, a community of scholars and professionals building an enduring legacy for future generations. Membership in Phi Kappa Phi is earned through nomination by a local school chapter.

links.title: UW Center for South Asia
links.description:
During the summers of 2008 and 2009, I participated in two 8-week, 160-hour South Asia Summer Language Institute (SASLI) intensive language programs equivalent to one full year of study each in Hindi and Sanskrit.

Since the summer of 2003, the UW Language Program Office and the UW Center for South Asia have provided first- through third-year study of nearly a dozen South Asian languages to support pedagogy, implement newly-developed language-learning tools, and increase the number and quality of trained specialists in each language.

links.id: About UW College Year in India

links.title: NSEP Boren Award Recipient
links.description:
Upon being selected as one of several dozen awardees of the 2009-2010 National Security Education Program (NSEP), I participated in the University of Wisconsin 9-month study abroad in Varanasi, India.

The NSEP fosters a pipeline of foreign language and cultural expertise critical to the U.S. federal government workforce, and was established by Congress in 1991 to encourage work in qualifying national security positions with a minimum one year service requirement.

Since its creation in 1973, the University of Wisconsin's College Year in India program has emphasized academic rigor and fieldwork. Students participate in immersive language coursework and in-depth research of an approved topic relating the student's major field of study, and must also complete a 3-month intensive summer language immersion course prior to the start of the program year.

items.title: Multi-Disciplined Civilian Analyst
items.description: To fulfill my National Security Education Program post-graduation service requirement, I was hired as a civilian analyst at the U.S. Department of Defense. I contributed to critical national security projects using my linguistic and technical expertise after passing a full background investigation to obtain my clearance. I also met and married my wife Maria, who happened to be in the same cohort of new hires at that time.

links.title: Certified CompTIA IT Fundamentals
links.description:
Federal Government IT workers are required to earn and maintain baseline certifications in the relevant field of work for the duration of their tenure.

CompTIA IT Fundamentals certification confirms foundational IT knowledge and skills. To earn this certification, individuals must demonstrate an understanding computer hardware and software, basic networking concepts, troubleshooting techniques, cybersecurity awareness, and familiarity with IT terminology.

links.title: Certified CompTIA Network+
links.description:
Federal Government IT workers are required to earn and maintain baseline certifications in the relevant field of work for the duration of their tenure.

CompTIA Network+ certification confirms an individual possesses the skills in networking required to troubleshoot, configure and manage both wired and wireless networks found in companies around the world. The certification requires a professional-level understanding of emerging technologies including cloud and virtualization technologies.

links.title: Certified CompTIA Security+
links.description:
Federal Government IT workers are required to earn and maintain baseline certifications in the relevant field of work for the duration of their tenure.

CompTIA Security+ certification confirms the baseline skills required to perform core security functions, and provides a global benchmark for best practices in IT network and operational security. The certifications requires hands-on practical experience in risk assessment and management, incident response, forensics, enterprise networks, hybrid/cloud operations, and security controls.

items.title: Bachelor of Sciences in Software Development & Security
items.description: In order to better support critical national security initiatives, I returned to school on a part-time remote basis to pursue a second degree in secure software development. In the course of my studies, I worked in small groups on both iterative and waterfall projects, while while extensively studying the OWASP Top 10 web application risks to ensure that security considerations were incorporated at all phases of development.

links.title: Secure Software Developer
links.description:
The Software Development and Security degree at University of Maryland Global Campus (formerly University of Maryland University College) is designed to teach programming languages and best practices in software development that are in demand today in the workplace. This degree supports technical and leadership roles in diverse and challenging application development and security settings, including high-demand positions such as software development and security analyst, software development and security manager, application and software architect, information security officer, intrusion analyst, penetration tester, programmer, software engineer, security and code auditor, or system architect.

Coursework includes studying leading industry practices and standards to meet user requirements, exploring all phases of a secure software development project as part of a software development team, using appropriate tools to analyze existing applications for weaknesses in order to mitigate security threats, and responding to cyberattacks to minimize risk and protect privacy. This degree requires the successful completion of 120 credits of coursework, including 33 credits for the major, 41 credits in general education requirements; and 46 credits in the minor, electives, and other degree requirements.

items.title: Software Engineer
items.description: With shifting policymaking priorities, I saw the opportunity to return to my roots and focus exclusively on software engineering in the private sector. I found that Sentry Insurance had some exciting projects as they moved away from iterative development on a legacy mainframe to cloud-based hosting using an agile software development model. During this period, my wife and I also welcomed our daughter Miri into our family.

links.title: Certified SAFe 4 Scrum Master
links.description:
After being asked to step into a more hands-on role in planning and executing on prioritized work within the software development lifecycle, I pursued and obtained a SAFe Scrum Master designation from Scaled Agile, Inc.

The SAFe Scrum Master certification recognizes expertise in Scrum, Lean, and Agile methodologies by demonstrating knowledge, skills, and experience required to manage Agile projects in a large-scale enterprise through an understanding of SAFe practices. This required enrolling in accredited courses offered by Scaled Agile and passing an exam to assess my ability to apply the principles of the SAFe framework.

links.title: Certified PolicyCenter 10.0 Specialist
links.description:
To deepen my expertise in the Guidewire suite of insurance software, I pursued and obtained a professional designation in Policy Center configuration.

The Guidewire PolicyCenter 10.0 Specialist certification recognizes professionals with a deep understanding of the insurance industry's leading software platform. This required long-term study in order to pass a series of exams evaluating my understanding of the key features of Guidewire software.

items.title: Web Application Developer
items.description: In my free time, I continue to work on various side projects combining my interest in software engineering and world history. Check out some of my most recent work showcasing my coding approach and attention to detail.

links.title: OldWorldSaints.com
links.description:
During the COVID-19 pandemic, I designed, built, and deployed this Spring Boot Java web application as a concept plan for the former UW Madison Lubar Institute for the Study of the Abrahamic Religions.

This site displays information about important figures and commemorations in various traditions through the ancient and medieval world. It includes scrollable and clickable maps built using Leaflet JS, links to scanned primary source materials in PDF format, and multiple search interfaces keying on a range of possible criteria.
